docs.title: Jonas Pangerl
docs.text:
CFD Engineer in Formula 1 at the Audi F1 Team,

Previously 3 years at Williams Racing as an Aerodynamicist,

Before that, 4 years in Formula Student focusing on Aerodynamics.

docs.title: About this site
docs.text: This is my personal website to share resources, notes, and tools, mainly for the Formula Student community. You will find talk materials, small utilities, and references that can help with aero and CFD workflows.

docs.title: What you will find here
docs.text:
• My path to F1 How I got into Formula 1, Journey to F1.

  • Talks and Presentations Slide decks and supporting material for quick download after events.

  • Tools and Utilities A small 2D boundary layer meshing setup tool for CFD, it computes BL mesh setup parameters and visualizes them so you can plug them into your meshing workflow, Boundary Layer Mesh Helper.

  • Quick Links and References Curated links I often share with students and colleagues.

docs.title: Services (Consulting)
docs.text:
I am available for consulting, - Aerodynamic Development, concept studies, CFD methodology, wind tunnel correlation, test planning and analysis, - Software Engineering, Python first, scripting, data tooling, automation pipelines, GUI apps for desktop and web, packaging and deployment,

If you need short term help, a code review, or a small tool built around your data, feel free to reach out. Consulting services are provided privately, outside of my employment, and only where non conflicting and compliant with employer policies.

docs.title: Skills Snapshot
docs.text:
• Formula 1 Aerodynamics, about 6 years, across aero, wind tunnel testing, and CFD,
  • Programming, Python for scripting, data tooling, packaging, Java for utilities, C++ basic exposure, GUIs and apps with PyQt, Streamlit, FastAPI, standalone tools for engineers,
  • Data Analysis and Visualization, reporting and dashboards,
  • CFD Tools and Methods, OpenFOAM, STAR CCM+, preprocessing, meshing, setup, post processing, correlation,
  • Collaboration, Git, code reviews, documentation, reproducible environments,

docs.title: Giving back to Formula Student
docs.text: I am very grateful for my Formula Student time, I learned a lot there, and I want to pass this knowledge on to students,     so that you can follow a similar path or take as much as possible from Formula Student.     Supporting the community is important to me, and I am happy to help where I can.

docs.title: Disclaimer

Product and company names are trademarks or registered trademarks of their respective holders, use does not imply affiliation or endorsement.

docs.title: Boundary Layer Meshing Setup Tool
docs.text: A lightweight tool to design boundary-layer (BL) meshes quickly and scientifically, before you spend time on full meshing runs.

docs.title: What it is
docs.text:
This Python-based desktop app helps you determine optimal boundary-layer mesh parameters in minutes. It visualizes and computes all relevant near-wall settings in real time, so you can pick robust values without waiting for a full meshing job.

GUI overview
  • Works great alongside OpenFOAM and STAR-CCM+ (and similar tools).
  • Focuses on external freestream flows with Reynolds numbers ~10⁴–10⁷.
  • Based on turbulent flat-plate theory for BL thickness and skin friction.

Download the tool from the link in the Downloads Page.

The tool is still in beta, so expect bugs. I would recomment to untick the "auto update" checkbox below the "Generate Mesh" button to increase stability. A new and more stable version will be released soon.

docs.title: Why this helps
docs.text:
If you’ve ever spent hours “dialing in” BL settings for a CFD case, you know the pain: - Picking the first cell height to hit your target y⁺, - Choosing the right BL thickness and number of layers, - Setting a geometric growth (stretch) factor, - Ensuring a smooth transition to the volume mesh.

This tool answers those questions instantly with live plots and metrics, so you can iterate scientifically—not by guesswork.

docs.title: What it calculates & shows
docs.text:
• Target y⁺ → suggests first cell height at the wall.
  • Boundary-layer thickness (theoretical) at a chosen station.
  • Number of BL layers and geometric stretch between layers.
  • Transition from BL mesh to volume mesh (first volume cell size).
  • Log-scale y⁺ plot and a mesh sketch for quick sanity checks.
  • Layer distribution across viscous sublayer, buffer, and log region.

The output parameters can be plugged into STAR-CCM+, OpenFOAM, ANSYS, ANSA, …

docs.title: Typical workflow
docs.text:
1. Set flow conditions (U∞, ν, characteristic length / Re).
  2. Choose target y⁺ → tool proposes first cell height.
  3. Pick BL thickness & number of layers; adjust stretch factor.
  4. Inspect the preview plots (mesh sketch + y⁺ log plot).
  5. Export or note the final set of mesh parameters.

docs.title: Parameters at a glance
docs.text: Parameter Meaning / Use Target y⁺ Near-wall resolution objective (e.g., 1 for low-Re models, 30–100 for wall functions). First Cell Height Calculated wall-adjacent cell size to hit the target y⁺. BL Thickness Theoretical boundary-layer thickness at your station. Number of Layers Layers in the BL block (sets resolution normal to the wall). Geometric Stretch Growth factor between successive layers (controls smoothness/stability). First Volume Cell Size Cell height immediately after BL block, ensuring smooth transition.

docs.title: Assumptions & limits
docs.text:
• Uses turbulent flat-plate correlations → a first estimate for real geometries.
  • Local skin friction, velocity, pressure gradients in your final flow field may differ. Expect to tune values once you see first results from your CFD mesh/solution.
  • Best suited for external flows in Re ≈ 10⁴–10⁷.

!!! note The tool is designed to narrow the search for workable BL parameters before you invest time in heavy meshing/solving. Use it to bracket sensible settings fast.

docs.title: Download & usage
docs.text:
Download the latest version from the Downloads Page.

No installation required: extract the ZIP and run the executable. For details, see the integrated Help tab.

docs.title: Compatibility
docs.text:
• CFD tools: OpenFOAM, STAR-CCM+, ANSYS/Fluent, ANSA (parameter transfer by hand or scripts).
  • OS: Windows (tested). Python source can be adapted for other platforms.

docs.text: Questions, feedback, or feature requests? I’m happy to help—also available for consulting around aerodynamic development and Python tooling.

docs.title: My journey to F1
docs.text:
This page summarizes how I moved from curiosity about aerodynamics to working in Formula 1.

Rennstall Esslingen Williams Racing Kick Sauber

docs.title: Early interests
docs.text: I was always fascinated by aerodynamics, aircraft and race cars inspired me early on. I first considered studying aerospace engineering, it felt a bit too narrow for me, so I chose a broader path with more future options. I studied Mechatronics in my bachelor but quickly realised that I enjoyed the mechanical engineering side the most, and also programming, so I steered my electives toward mechanics, aerodynamics, CFD, and applied maths.

docs.title: Studies
docs.text: I continued with a Master’s in Mechanical Engineering at the University of Applied Sciences Esslingen, the same place where I did my bachelor. I took every course I could find that touched aerodynamics, CFD, and the maths behind them. I did not plan on Formula 1 at that time, it felt unrealistic and was not a goal.

docs.title: Formula Student
docs.text:
During my bachelor thesis I joined Rennstall Esslingen, the Formula Student team of the UAS Esslingen in the aerodynamics group. The year before I had designed a Formula 1 style front wing at home for fun and to lear how surface design works in CAD. It is linked on the downloads page and I also published it on GrabCAD: https://grabcad.com/jonas.pangerl-1/models.

  • Year 1, I worked on the front wing and the diffuser
  • Year 2, I became aero lead, I reworked the STARCCM+ simulation model, automated processes and post processing, and with the team I developed a new aero concept for 2019 that performed very well and we won Formula Student Germany 2019 with a completely new car
  • Year 3, I was involved in the early concept work on a fan car, the project was refined by a colleague, the next season was extremely successful, including another FSG win and World Ranking Number 1. In that year I also reworked the CFD process a second time from scratch to make it more flexible and also much faster.
  • Year 4, I reworked the front wing of the car with the goal to make it less ride height dependent and more aerodynamically stable by providing high CpT to the downstream parts of the car. The team still uses the main shapes of this wing years later

docs.title: First industry step
docs.text: At FS Spain 2019, a judge from Williams Racing noticed my work in the Engineering Design event and Williams offered me an internship in the aerodynamics department. This year at Williams was an amazing learning experience.

docs.title: Thesis and research
docs.text: I wrote my Master’s thesis in the CFD group at Williams, focusing on high fidelity simulations of a Formula One wing and wheel configuration in OpenFOAM, mostly LES and DES, at very high resolution (quasi DNS). I compared modelling approaches, conducted studies, and produced a dataset that Williams could reuse internally for further projects.

docs.title: Williams, aero work
docs.text: After the thesis, I stayed at Williams in the aerodynamics department, as an aerodynamicist working on the floor. This deepened my understanding of development cycles, WT testing, correlation and robust workflow design.

docs.title: Move to Switzerland, CFD correlation
docs.text: After three years at Williams I moved to Sauber (now AudiF1) in Switzerland and shifted my path towards CFD. I now work in the CFD correlation team, which fits my strengths from aero development and my thesis work. It is varied and challenging, and there is still a lot to learn from my colleagues and the people in the CFD methodology team.

docs.title: What helped most
docs.text:
• Fundamentals, fluid mechanics, numerics, and data analysis
  • Building things that others can see, tools, case studies
  • Python for scripting, automation, visualisation, documentation
  • Teamwork and ownership in Formula Student, leading, reviewing, iterating
  • Sharing results in a way that is easy to understand and discussing with colleagues
  • Having fun doing all those things

docs.title: Practical advice for students
docs.text:
• Grades matter less than skill growth and visible work,
  • Learn beyond the syllabus, books, videos, open projects,
  • Use Formula Student to try ideas and to deliver something new,
  • Stand out with good documentation and consistent results,
  • Reach out to teams, network at events, ask for feedback, apply anyway.

docs.title: Inside an F1 Aero Department, a Practical Sketch
docs.text:
This section explains how a Formula 1 aero department is structured, it gives the background of the regulations and why things are done the way they are in F1 aero, also in comparison to other industries where time, cost, and regulation constraints can be very different. The goal is to provide an overview of how the organisation typically looks, which sub departments are usually present, what the main tasks are, and which interests and skills help you work there, or help you decide if a given area could be a good fit for you.

I also want to make clear how the different groups interact, concept to CAD to CFD to wind tunnel to track, and how information flows in both directions, factory to track and back. The purpose is to give you a quick map so you can see yourself in it, and so you can better understand what to apply for when you browse F1 team career pages.

Please note, this is a sketch from my personal experience and conversations. Every team is different and this does not represent my current team. Names differ between teams, some tasks may live in different departments, take this as a broad overview that should still help you understand how things work in general.

docs.title: Table of contents for this section
docs.text:
• Regulations
  • Aero Development
  • Surfacing
  • Model Design
  • Wind Tunnel Testing
  • CFD
  • Software
  • Aero Performance

docs.title: Aero Performance
docs.text: Aero Performance connects the factory with the track, the focus is the actual race car and its aerodynamic behaviour in real conditions. The group prepares events in advance, supports the car live during sessions, and feeds learning back to the factory.

docs.title: Preparation, before the event
docs.text:
• Build aero run plans for the circuit, expected ride heights, steering ranges, yaw distributions, speed points,
  • Define downforce levels, for example low or high configurations, target the best lap time for the expected conditions,
  • Prepare cooling levels and specs, predict temperature margins for engine and brakes,
  • Run simulations to explore trade offs, aero maps for load and balance, drag versus top speed, sensitivity to wind and temperature,
  • Align references with CFD and WT so comparisons and corrections are consistent.

docs.title: At the track, live operations
docs.text:
• Select aero and cooling levels based on ambient conditions, track evolution, and forecast,
  • Monitor live telemetry and run sheets, validate that the car sits in the intended aero window,
  • Track consistency across sessions and stints, understand drift and reset conditions, support setup choices,
  • Diagnose issues in real time, if a part is damaged, use load cells, suspension sensors, and pressure taps to estimate aero loss and
  • decide whether to pit or stay out.

docs.title: Correlation, closing the loop
docs.text: Some teams handle correlation inside Aero Performance, some do it jointly with CFD and WT. The group compares track behaviour with factory predictions, * Align conditions and references, temperatures, ride heights, yaw, steer, * Compare forces and balances against CFD and WT expectations, * Identify where models are off and feed findings back to the factory.

docs.title: Collaboration touchpoints
docs.text:
• Vehicle Performance, align on lap time models, tyre behaviour, and strategy constraints,
  • Aero development, communicate track sensitivities and priorities, request options where the car needs help,
  • CFD, share deviations and needed studies, keep references aligned for correlation,
  • WT testing, agree on references and corrections used at the track, request checks when needed,

docs.title: Skills and interests
docs.text:
• Solid understanding of aerodynamics and flow physics, ability to read sensitivity not only single points,
  • Practical coding for automation and data handling, Python is very useful for pipelines and plots,
  • Familiarity with data acquisition and telemetry, comfort with sensors and signals,
  • Awareness of strategy and vehicle performance context, so aero choices are judged by lap time, not by isolated forces.

docs.title: Aero Development
docs.text: When people say F1 aero development, they usually refer to the work of Aerodynamicists. These engineers create and evolve concepts, build parts in a CAD environment, often with support from Surfacers, run CFD through automated pipelines, and evaluate results to decide the next steps. The goal is to shape the flow field around the car so that downforce goes up, drag goes down, and sensitivities move in a helpful direction.

docs.title: Typical workflow, concept to decision
docs.text:
1. Idea and intent, define a flow objective, for example a stronger floor sealing vortex, a cleaner front wheel wake, a more stable diffuser structure
  2. CAD surfaces, create water tight surfaces that express the idea, keep packaging and legality in mind, request surfacing support where useful
  3. CFD release, place the option into a fully automated CFD process
  4. Post processing, review forces and moments, surface pressure and total pressure, flow structures and vortex criteria, compare with a clean reference
  5. Multi condition view, inspect the option across relevant ride heights, yaws, steering, rake, front and rear heights
  6. Decision, refine and loop, or prepare a WT release, or drop the concept if evidence is weak

docs.title: Conditions and sensitivities
docs.text: F1 parts can behave very differently across conditions. A floor edge that helps at low ride height can be neutral or negative at high ride height, a front wing tweak that looks good at zero yaw can hurt at high yaw. Aero development therefore balances overall load levels and drag, gradients across ride height, yaw, steer, speed, robustness to setup variation.

docs.title: Reading the data
docs.text:
Aerodynamicists look at

  • Forces and moments, trends and deltas against a stable reference
  • Surface fields, pressure coefficient and total pressure, separation lines, attachment quality
  • Volume fields, vortex cores, shear layers, losses, ...
  • Diagnostics, numerical and aerodynamic health, reference alignment for correlation

docs.title: Wind tunnel handover and testing
docs.text: After several CFD iterations the option can go to the wind tunnel. Aerodynamicists hand water tight surfaces to Model Design, which splits and prepares parts for the WT model. Depending on the team, aerodynamicists may also cover WT shifts, or a dedicated WT group runs the plan. Results return to the aero development owner for analysis and a decision, release to track, iterate, or stop.

docs.title: Correlation mindset
docs.text: Aero development checks how CFD predictions compare with WT. Differences can point to modelling gaps, measurement limits, or concept sensitivity. Good notes and clean comparisons make later decisions faster.

docs.title: Collaboration touchpoints
docs.text:
• Surfacers, help turn quick design intent into clean surfaces
  • CFD group, keeps pipelines reliable, advises on meshing and numerics, maintains standards
  • Model Design, translates surfaces into WT hardware, plans splits, interfaces, stiffness
  • WT testing, executes plans, controls change times, secures repeatability
  • Aero Performance, provides track context and priorities

docs.title: Skills and interests checklist
docs.text:
• Strong CAD fundamentals, comfortable building clean, water tight surfaces
  • Practical CFD literacy, release options into automated workflows, read field data with purpose
  • Curiosity for flow physics, ability to form testable hypotheses
  • Statistical sense for multi condition behaviour, read gradients, not only single points
  • Clear communication, concise plots and notes, evidence you and others can act on
  • Planning ability for WT releases, understanding of constraints and measurement options

docs.title: CFD
docs.text: The CFD group looks after the full chain from CAD to post processing. They work very closely with Software inside Aero, in some teams both are one department, here we focus on CFD. The goal is fast, robust, and accurate simulation that Aero development can rely on for decisions and correlation.

docs.title: The pipeline, CAD to mesh to solve to post
docs.text:
1. CAD preparation, enforce naming and structure, export with stable references and units, simple and repeatable export macros help a lot,
  2. Meshing, generate a robust mesh with predictable boundary layer settings and wake resolution, guardrail checks for skewness, non orthogonality, cell count, y plus targets,
  3. Solving, choose numerics and turbulence models with fast turnaround and acceptable accuracy, monitor residuals and forces,
  4. Post processing, create standard figures and tables, forces and moments, surface pressure and total pressure, vortex criteria and sections, all compared to a clean reference and ready to compare with WT,

docs.title: Correlation focus
docs.text: Part of the team studies the differences between CFD, WT, and track. They align conditions and references, they maintain correlation cases, and they suggest setup improvements.

docs.title: Methods and fidelity
docs.text: The workhorse is RANS, Reynolds Averaged Navier Stokes, chosen for speed and coverage across many conditions. When budget allows, the team can also runs higher fidelity cases, for example LES or DES, to study specific flow physics. Efficient numerics and smart meshing let you simulate more conditions per geometry, or to spend effort on fewer but deeper cases.

docs.title: Efficiency under regulations
docs.text:
Within an ATR period the team budgets MAUH for numerical effort and counts RATG for geometry changes. Efficient pipelines allow

  • more conditions per RATG when running RANS,
  • or the use of LES and DES on selected flows where the extra insight is worth the cost,
  • Either way, reliable automation and templated setups are essential.

docs.title: Tooling
docs.text: Teams commonly use OpenFOAM, some also run STARCCM+ or Ansys Fluent.

docs.title: Skills and interests
docs.text:
• Strong CFD fundamentals, numerics, turbulence modelling,
  • Scripting, data handling, automation, plotting,
  • Basic understanding of the flow physics,
  • Familiarity with OpenFOAM is a strong plus at most teams, data analytics skills are very useful.

docs.title: Model Design
docs.text: Model design engineers take the final wetted surfaces from Aeros and Surfacing and turn them into wind tunnel model hardware. The focus is not to invent shapes, it is to scale to 60 percent, to split intelligently, to ensure modularity and quick change times in the tunnel, to hit stiffness targets, to place instrumentation, and to deliver parts that assemble cleanly and repeatably.

docs.title: Typical workflow
docs.text:
1. Intake and sanity checks, confirm version, scale to 60 percent, confirm references, check water tightness
  2. Split strategy, define parting lines, flanges, datum scheme, fastener positions, inserts, access for assembly
  3. Modularity design, design quick change interfaces so options can be swapped fast, minimise change time in the tunnel
  4. Stiffness and aero elasticity, choose thicknesses and local reinforcements, plan materials so parts deflect as intended
  5. Instrumentation, route pressure probe lines, add tap bosses, connector blocks, cable and tube management
  6. Manufacturing plan, select processes, rapid prototyping, CNC, composites, define tolerances and finishes

docs.title: Split lines and interfaces
docs.text:
Good splits make the tunnel day easier.

  • Keep datum features clear, locators and pins, repeatable assembly, minimal shimming
  • Put fasteners where access is easy, design for tool reach and quick swaps
  • Keep sealing and edges clean so the aero surface is preserved after assembly
  • Group options into modules so a single change does not force a large disassembly

docs.title: Instrumentation and services
docs.text:
Wind tunnel models carry plumbing and sensors.

  • Pressure taps and manifolds, short and consistent tube lengths, clear labelling, leak test steps in the build doc
  • Provision for deflection measurement, optical targets or probes
  • Cable and tube routing that does not compromise assembly, sealing, or surface quality

docs.title: Automation and templates
docs.text:
Repetition is common, automation pays off.

  • Parametric template parts for flanges, tap bosses, inserts, connectors
  • CAD macros and scripts for export, drawing stamps, ballooning, file naming
  • Checkers for minimum radii, wall thickness, hole clearances, thread depths

docs.title: Collaboration touchpoints
docs.text:
• Aerodevelopment, confirm intent, agree on swap strategy and test priorities
  • Surfacing, resolve issues with patch layouts and continuity near splits
  • WT testing, align on change time goals, access, fixtures, spares
  • Purchasing and suppliers, lead times, material choices, post processing, deliveries

docs.title: Skills and interests checklist
docs.text:
• Strong CAD skills, assembly design, robust references, clean drawings
  • Practical sense for modularity, assembly, and serviceability
  • Understanding of materials and manufacturing processes, SLA, SLS, MJF, CNC, composites
  • Care for instrumentation, pressure systems, cable and tube management
  • Habit of documenting, naming, and versioning so others can work fast

docs.title: Regulations, what frames F1 aero work
docs.text: This page summarises where the rules live and how they constrain day-to-day aero work. The Formula One Sporting Regulations and the Technical Regulations define the car’s aerodynamic rules, how parts may deflect and what loads they must withstand under specified conditions, how testing is performed and limited, and how wind tunnel and CFD activities are controlled and measured.

docs.title: Testing periods, how allocations are handed out
docs.text: Aerodynamic testing, both WT and CFD, is restricted by an Aerodynamic Testing Regulations period (ATR). An ATR period is typically about eight weeks. Each team receives an allowance per period that scales with championship position, teams further back receive more allocation, teams at the front receive less. The counters above, runs, wind on time, occupancy, must all fit within that allowance.

docs.title: Wind tunnel testing
docs.text: Wind tunnel activity is bounded by three counters, the goal is to extract maximum information per plan while staying within the allocation. The WT model is limited to a 60% scale model and the maximum windspeed to 50m/s.

docs.title: 1) Runs
docs.text: A run is counted when the speed in the test section rises above a defined threshold and, at the next time it falls back below the threshold, that completes one run. Teams are allowed only a certain number of runs per ATR period.

docs.title: 2) Wind on time
docs.text: Wind on time is the accumulated time while the test section speed is above the threshold. Every second above that threshold adds to the counter, the total wind on time per period is limited.

docs.title: 3) Occupancy
docs.text: Occupancy is the time spent working on the tunnel model and rig, even when the wind is off. This time is also limited, so planning and short change times are essential.

docs.title: CFD testing
docs.text: CFD activity is controlled by the declared compute resource and by counters that measure numerical effort and geometry change.

docs.title: Declared resource
docs.text: Each team declares a HPC resource to the FIA, activity runs on that resource and is monitored.

docs.title: MAUH, numerical effort
docs.text: MAUH (Mega Allocation Unit Hours) represents the numerical effort available within one ATR period. You budget this across your simulations. More efficient setups and numerics let you run more conditions within the same MAUH, heavier models reduce the count but may give deeper insight.

docs.title: RATG, restricted aerodynamic testing geometry
docs.text: RATG counts surface geometry changes. One RATG is counted when the surface mesh changes by more than 0.5 mm. Geometry changes are limited per period, for example on the order of ~2000 RATGs in 2025. The more efficiently you run, the more driving conditions you can simulate per RATG, or you spend MAUH on higher-fidelity studies such as LES or DES instead of more RANS conditions.

docs.title: Why all of this matters, process efficiency
docs.text:
These constraints make efficient, automated processes mandatory, from CAD to meshing to run control to post-processing and correlation. Teams aim to

  • minimise change and setup times,
  • standardise and template common steps,
  • maximise useful data recorded per run and per simulation,
  • align CFD and WT conditions so correlation is quick and trustworthy.

docs.title: Software
docs.text: The software group builds and maintains the tools that Aero relies on every day, they connect data from track, wind tunnel, CFD, and CAD, they store it, validate it, and make it easy to search, to compare, to visualise, and to document. Most tools are in house, the group responds quickly to requests from Aerodynamicists and provides APIs and libraries so other departments can use the same data without friction.

docs.title: Core responsibilities
docs.text:
• Data ingestion, bring telemetry, WT logs, CFD results, and CAD exports into consistent formats,
  • Storage and models, design schemas that reflect how work happens, runs, options, references, conditions,
  • Processing and QC, validate units and references, detect outliers, compute derived signals and deltas,
  • APIs and access, stable services for reading and writing, good documentation and examples,
  • Applications, web or desktop apps for search, comparison, visualisation, and reporting,
  • Automation, scheduled jobs and event driven pipelines, predictable artefacts for engineers.

docs.title: Where software sits in the loop
docs.text: Software works closely with CFD and WT, because these are the main producers of data, and with Aero development and Aero Performance, because these are the main consumers. The goal is one shared picture across factory and track, so decisions are made on the same evidence.

docs.title: Skills and profile
docs.text:
• Solid software engineering skills, clean code, tests, reviews, version control,
  • Python for data and glue, comfort with APIs and small web apps,
  • Understanding of aero development, enough to speak the language and to prioritise useful features,
  • Interest in data modelling and UX, so engineers find things and apply them quickly.

docs.title: Surfacing
docs.text: Surfacing engineers turn aerodynamic intent into clean, water-tight CAD. They understand the regulations well, they can visualise complex 3D shapes, and they know how to build robust models that can be edited safely by Aerodynamicists later. Input often arrives as sketches, screenshots, short briefs, or design notes, output is a surface model that fits packaging and legality and is ready for CFD and model design.

docs.title: Typical workflow
docs.text:
1. Intake and brief, clarify the idea, targets, affected zones, constraints, references
  2. Scaffolding, set up construction geometry, key sections, rails, wireframes, guides
  3. Primary surfacing, create continuous, high-quality patches, enforce curvature goals
  4. Legality support, run checks, add helper features for automated legality checking where useful
  5. Robustness pass, organise history, name features, stabilise dependencies for future edits
  6. Handover, deliver water-tight surfaces to Aerodynamicists, note change knobs and limits
  7. Feedback loop, review CFD and WT outcomes to refine patterns and standards

docs.title: What “clean CAD” means
docs.text:
• Water-tightness, no gaps, no inverted normals, closed volumes where required
  • Continuity, control of G0, G1, G2 as appropriate, smooth blends, no ripples
  • Topology discipline, logical patch layout, minimal and stable trim lines
  • Sensible parameterisation, editable rails and sections, protected references
  • Legality awareness, surfaces carry or respect reference planes and envelopes

docs.title: Collaboration touchpoints
docs.text:
• Aerodevelopment, translate intent into shapes, expose safe edit handles, agree naming and file structure
  • CFD group, ensure surfaces import cleanly, meshing tolerances make sense, fix pain points quickly
  • Model Design, confirm splits, flanges, inserts, minimum radii, thickness, and stiffness needs
  • Legality and standards, align on automated checks, shared references, and macros

docs.title: Legality and standards
docs.text: Surfacing often helps by baking in or checking geometry rules. * Maintain shared reference geometry, legality planes, boxes, keep-outs Provide simple check features or layer tags so automated scripts can validate quickly Keep unit systems, tolerances, naming, and layer conventions consistent

docs.title: Building for change
docs.text: The best surfaces are robust against edits, because concepts evolve quickly. * Favour stable wireframes and sectional control, avoid fragile chains of trims Keep a shallow history where possible, reduce cross-part dependencies Name features clearly, expose edit parameters for the common change requests Store before and after* variants for quick reversions and A–B comparisons

docs.title: Skills and interests checklist
docs.text:
• Strong CAD fundamentals, curvature control, patch layout, trimming, joining
  • Good 3D imagination and spatial reasoning, comfort working in sections and guides
  • Appreciation of aero needs and meshing needs, understand what helps CFD and WT
  • Curiosity for feedback, CFD results, WT outcomes

docs.title: Wind Tunnel Testing
docs.text: The wind tunnel team operates the facility, they integrate and maintain measurement systems, they ensure runs are reliable, repeatable, and efficient. They keep boundary layer control, rolling road systems, balances, drives, safety, and software in good shape, and they optimise procedures so runs are short while still capturing all important conditions.

docs.title: Core responsibilities
docs.text:
• Facility operation, schedule, startup and shutdown, monitoring of fans, drives, controls, safety systems,
  • Model responsibility, the wind tunnel model is a different car than the race car, it matches the outer surfaces but is a purpose built test article with its own structure, services, and interfaces,
  • Change management, quick and clean swaps, fixtures and tools that minimise change time, clear checklists for each change,
  • Calibration and QA, balances, pressure systems, optical systems, rolling road alignment, leak checks, repeatability studies,
  • Data integrity, synchronised acquisition across systems, reference alignment, automated sanity checks.

docs.title: Systems they look after
docs.text:
• Boundary layer control, suction slots and plenums, control logic, health checks,
  • Rolling road, belt tracking, speed control, force and moment corrections, thermal management,
  • Balances and load paths, load cells, six component balances, alignment and tare procedures,
  • Pressure systems, taps, manifolds, tubing, conditioning, leak tests,
  • Optical measurement, PIV or deflection cameras, lighting and seeding systems,
  • Flow probes, total and static pressure probes, five hole probes, traverses and positioning,
  • Environment, temperature and humidity monitoring, repeatable conditioning where possible.

docs.title: Software and automation
docs.text:
WT testing benefits from automation everywhere,

  • Run control, scripted sequences for condition sweeps, automatic checks before each acquisition,
  • Acquisition, unified triggers and timestamps, loss detection and retries,
  • Procedures, digital checklists, interlocks, reminders,
  • Post processing, first pass results available right after a run, plots and deltas against a reference,
  • Maintenance, dashboards for health, calibrations due, sensor drift.

docs.title: Measurement techniques and quality
docs.text:
The team integrates techniques to see not only forces but also flow behaviour,

  • Forces and moments, primary quality gate for development decisions,
  • Surface pressures, dense tap fields on selected parts, quick diagnostics for trends,
  • Deflection measurement, optical targets or displacement probes to separate aero effect from structural movement,
  • PIV or probe based flow, targeted planes to understand the volume flow field.

docs.title: Continuous improvement and new tech
docs.text:
WT teams scout and trial new methods from vendors and other industries,

  • Evaluate practicality and gain, integrate into procedures, train users, measure impact on repeatability and change time,

docs.title: Collaboration touchpoints
docs.text:
• Aero development, align on run plans and priorities, agree on references and comparisons,
  • Model Design, plan splits and interfaces that reduce change time, plan instrumentation early,
  • CFD group, align conditions for correlation, share data.

docs.title: Skills and interests checklist
docs.text:
• Understanding of aerodynamics and test methods,
  • Comfort with electronics and instrumentation, hands on attitude,
  • Interest in process optimisation and automation,
  • Basic coding for scripts and data handling,
  • Care for measurement quality, calibration, traceability, documentation.
